Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Design, Chemistry and Study of Systems for Making Solar Hydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program supports a four-way collaboration between Professors Richard Eisenberg and David W. McCamant of the University of Rochester and Michael R. Detty and David Watson of the University at Buffalo on new systems for the visible light-driven generation of hydrogen from aqueous protons, and associated photochemical and photophysical investigations to fully understand this critical transformation. The reaction corresponds to the reductive side of water splitting, which is the key reaction in artificial photosynthesis and the conversion of light into stored chemical potential energy. The research focuses on: (1) systems containing new or unstudied chromophores for light absorption and electron transfer, and catalysts for proton reduction; and (2) systems integration since the robustness and activity of different components affect each other.

Abundant, environmentally-benign energy for sustainable development is one of this century's great scientific and technological challenges, and solar energy conversion is the key long-term strategy to solving this problem. Through the Chemical Catalysis Program, this collaborative research effort will contribute to the fundamental science on which future energy technology can be built and implemented. The entire concept of a hydrogen economy relies on an efficient and robust means to carry out water splitting using the sun as the primary energy source. The broader impacts of the research will manifest themselves in two major ways. First, through the research accomplished, greater knowledge about the reductive side of water splitting will be gained. For the most viable new systems for hydrogen generation, connection to a successful module for water oxidation may yield a system for solar splitting of water. Second, new scientists will be educated and trained to work in this challenging and important subject.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research :  "The Design, Chemistry and Study of Systems for Making Solar Hydrogen.” (04/01/2012-03/31/2016)

 

Michael R. Detty, P.I.

David F. Watson, co-P.I.

Department of Chemistry, University at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY  14260

 

This project involved a four-way collaboration between Professors David McCamant (DM) and Richard Eisenberg (RE) of the University of Rochester (UR), and Michael R. Detty (MD) and David Watson (DW) of the University at Buffalo (UB). The project was supported by NSF Grants CHE-1151789 and CHE-1151379 made separately to the University of Rochester and the University at Buffalo. 

Intellectual Merit:  Each of the main investigators brought to the collaborative research different but overlapping perspectives and skills that led to significant new results on a fundamentally challenging problem in solar energy conversion. DM is an ultrafast spectroscopist with expertise in photophysics and time domain methods; RE possesses expertise in inorganic photochemistry and the light-driven generation of hydrogen; MD is an expert in physical organic methods and the synthesis and chemistry of dyes; and DW is a materials scientist studying modified semi-conductor surfaces and their properties. The collaboration has made progress on new systems for the light-driven generation of hydrogen. In the conversion of solar energy to stored chemical fuels, water splitting is the ideal energy storing reaction.  In this reaction, light from the sun is used to drive the chemical reaction 2H2O -> O2 + 2H2, thereby producing gaseous hydrogen in a sustainable manner for the next generation of energy production. The experiments accomplished via this grant have advanced the field of artificial photosynthesis by developing new molecules and molecular systems that can absorb light, transfer electrons, and use those electrons to produce hydrogen fuel. At Rochester, ultrafast laser experiments in the DM lab have been used to determine the speed with which dye molecules relax between different electronic states and eventually transfer electrons after absorbing light. Synthetic efforts in the RE lab have developed new molecular dyes that can absorb light across different ranges of the solar spectrum and that can bind to semiconductors to facilitate efficient electron transfer events.  At Buffalo, the MD lab has synthesized new carbon based dyes that absorb strongly in the visible part of the solar spectrum and DW has probed the nanosecond dynamics with which those dyes accomplish electron transfer to semiconductors.

Broader Impacts:  These studies have had broad impact on the field of solar energy conversion through the publication of 11 papers in scientific journals. Additionally, this grant has funded the training of one postdoctoral scholar, eight graduate students, and four undergraduate students at the University at Buffalo. All of the trained scientist have either gone on to careers in STEM education or research and development or are continuing their studies at the University at Buffalo.
